So I just found a really cool microscope that scans cells in 3D being marketed to teachers.

:thinking:

Neat :camera_with_flash:

yeah lab equipment is usually very expensive
ive had to buy adapters for a thermostat, just 100g of metal, not that hard to manufacture, like 200 € each
My mother's a teacher, but she doesn't do the science stuff and wouldn't need that.
she's elementary special ed
My mom isn't a sped specialist, but they gave her all of them this year.
it'd be a really, really expensive paperweight
Literally all of them.
So that they can all be graded on the same standards.
even though Special Ed is rated on a case-by-case basis because they /can't/ be graded by the same standards?
But it sucks because she has to spend so much time instructing them individually that the rest of the class has to wait around and twiddle their fingers.
Yeah, she has IEP meetings nonstop.
yeah that sounds like a major oversight
there's no like.. teacher union or whatnot?
cuz that's not how classes are supposed to be

you can't just put special ed kids in a normal classroom cuz that's just acting like special ed doesn't even exist

here in Louisiana, the highest a Special Ed class can have is 6, I believe
and that's w/ 3 adults
one for two kids

And the strike did jack all except screw up everyone's calendar.
Governor promised a "20%" pay increase to the teachers.
that doesn't solve shit though :/
But that includes the 1% they got this year.
And the 20% is split over 4 years.
And it's only based off of a starting teachers salary.
yeah so basically it comes out to about nothin
And only about half of the teachers are actually entitled to it.
"entitled" I mean they they are only willing to pay some of the teachers.
Physical education, tech education, the arts, and some other specializations aren't getting it.
So the individual city admins promised to split it up equally among them.
Did the math, and over the next 3 years, my dad's gonna see a whopping 3% increase.
IF and only IF the governor actually does what he promised.
The whole thing is still up in the air.
ooowee, what an increase! :U
not that it's gonna solve all the other problems
Not gonna solve a damned thing.
Folks voted against the strike actually.
They think the problem will go away if you throw money at it
They knew it was a bunch of bullshit, figured it'd be unfair to the students for them to miss a week of school just before finals.
but something like 79% of the state voted in favor of the strike.
As I hear it, many of the teachers voted against the strike. But a majority of the population that voted were people like administration and janitorial.
It's a buncha' horseshit, but whatcha gonna do.
well, the whole point of strikes is to raise awareness and question the conditions that the upper management is failing at. Sometimes it works, sometimes it don't, but
